head.supplied: Melbourne, ¶ 14 April 1890. ¶ Rob. Watson Esqr, ¶ Engineer in Chief of the Railway Department. ¶ The specimens of wood and branchlets, dear Mr Watson, received from your Department this afternoon, wer...

div.p: No 90/2629, unit 120, VPRS 425, inward registered correspondence, Engineer in Chief, VA 2876, Department of Railways, Public Record Office, Victoria.
Engineer in Chief of the Railway Department.

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 0in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: 0.4929in;

div.p:
The specimens of wood and branchlets, dear Mr Watson, received from your Department this afternoon, were unaccompanied by any letter, so I merely sent a brief memorandum,
See M to R. Watson, 14 April 1890. stating that they belonged to a variety of Eucalyptus rostrata, and that I thought, the timber might prove of fair durability. I did however not recommend it for railway sleepers; and as I have by the evening post received your letter of this day,
See R. Watson to M, 14 April 1890.
I would now beg to add, that as a Redgum-tree this variety is of an inferior kind, approaching somewhat certain states of the Manna-Gumtree, E. viminalis, which also varies considerably according to soil and situation. I would now advise that the Inspector at Myrtleford should allow wood of E. rostrata only to be taken for underground -work from spots, where darker and more solid timber is obtainable, that, from which the submitted specimens came, being likely cut at an exceptionally unfavorable locality.

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 1.75in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: 0in;
